verses.verse: For as often as you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death (John 14:3; (Acts 1:11)) till He comes.
Examine Yourself Therefore whoever eats ((John 6:51)) this bread or drinks this cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner will be guilty of the body and blood of the Lord.
But (Matt. 26:22; 2 Cor. 13:5; Gal. 6:4) let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of the bread and drink of the cup.
For he who eats and drinks in an unworthy manner eats and drinks judgment to himself, not discerning the Lord’s body.
For this reason many are weak and sick among you, and many sleep.
For ((Ps. 32:5; 1 John 1:9)) if we would judge ourselves, we would not be judged.
But when we are judged, (2 Sam. 7:14; Ps. 94:12; (Heb. 12:5-10; Rev. 3:19)) we are chastened by the Lord, that we may not be condemned with the world.
Therefore, my brethren, when you (1 Cor. 14:26) come together to eat, wait for one another.
But if anyone is hungry, let him eat at home, lest you come together for judgment. And the rest I will set in order when I come.
Spiritual Gifts: Unity in Diversity Now (1 Cor. 12:4; 14:1, 37) concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I do not want you to be ignorant:
You know (1 Cor. 6:11; Eph. 2:11; 1 Pet. 4:3) that you were Gentiles, carried away to these (Ps. 115:5; Is. 46:7; Jer. 10:5; Hab. 2:18) dumb idols, however you were led.
Therefore I make known to you that no one speaking by the Spirit of God calls Jesus accursed, and (Matt. 16:17) no one can say that Jesus is Lord except by the Holy Spirit.
(Rom. 12:3-8; 1 Cor. 12:11; Eph. 4:4, 11; Heb. 2:4) There are diversities of gifts, but (Eph. 4:4) the same Spirit.
(Rom. 12:6) There are differences of ministries, but the same Lord.
And there are diversities of activities, but it is the same God (1 Cor. 15:28; Eph. 1:23; 4:6) who works all in all.
But the manifestation of the Spirit is given to each one for the profit of all:
for to one is given (1 Cor. 2:6, 7; 2 Cor. 1:12) the word of wisdom through the Spirit, to another (Rom. 15:14; (1 Cor. 2:11, 16); 2 Cor. 8:7) the word of knowledge through the same Spirit,
(Matt. 17:19; (1 Cor. 13:2); 2 Cor. 4:13) to another faith by the same Spirit, to another (Matt. 10:1; Mark 3:15; 16:18; James 5:14) gifts of healings by the same Spirit,

(Mark 16:17) to another the working of miracles, to another (Rom. 12:6) prophecy, to another (1 John 4:1) discerning of spirits, to another (Acts 2:4-11) different kinds of tongues, to another the interpretation of tongues.
But one and the same Spirit works all these things, (Rom. 12:6; 2 Cor. 10:13) distributing to each one individually ((John 3:8)) as He wills.

Unity and Diversity in One Body For (Rom. 12:4, 5; 1 Cor. 10:17; Eph. 4:4) as the body is one and has many members, but all the members of that one body, being many, are one body, ((Gal. 3:16)) so also is Christ.

For ((Rom. 6:5)) by one Spirit we were all baptized into one body— (Rom. 3:22; Gal. 3:28; (Eph. 2:13-18); Col. 3:11) whether Jews or Greeks, whether slaves or free—and ((John 7:37-39)) have all been made to drink into one Spirit.
For in fact the body is not one member but many.
If the foot should say, “Because I am not a hand, I am not of the body,” is it therefore not of the body?
And if the ear should say, “Because I am not an eye, I am not of the body,” is it therefore not of the body?
If the whole body were an eye, where would be the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where would be the smelling?
But now (1 Cor. 12:28) God has set the members, each one of them, in the body (Rom. 12:3) just as He pleased.
And if they were all one member, where would the body be?
But now indeed there are many members, yet one body.
And the eye cannot say to the hand, “I have no need of you”; nor again the head to the feet, “I have no need of you.”
No, much rather, those members of the body which seem to be weaker are necessary.
